I have some experience shooting low contrast objects and maximizing their apparent contrast and viewability for the display medium - depending on how much you care and how faint you think they may appear, it's worth approaching properly. you want to shoot with a camera that will dump footage with a higher bit depth than the typical 8 bits per channel. I believe you have a Miro, I know its sensor is 12 bit native and will dump footage at 10 and 12bpc but I believe it used to be a paid option - worth looking into, you might already have it. overall dynamic range doesn't matter as much, the difference between the object you're exposing for and the bg is probably less than two stops. the important thing is encoding those two stops with as many bits as possible, so in post you can really stretch those stops out to make the difference more perceptible in typical 8bpc web encodes. the issue with doing that with 8bpc source footage is you have maybe two bits encoding said exposure range, so when you try to stretch them out you get really bad banding. might be worth looking into, might not. but like you said it happens once in a lifetime and you might be the first to get proper footage of them. feel free to contact me if you want more info, ensuring 10bpc processing in post is a whole other set of gotchas

Are you sure the shadow bands aren't refraction of light through solar winds? Hot gasses and what not being expelled by the sun cause the refraction but the bands are normally flooded by direct sun light. During a total solar eclipse the moon would block the direct light but not the refracted light from the winds which would arc around the moon. Once the eclipse reaches C2, the angle the light would need to arc around the moon is too great, therefore the bands go away. Once C3 occurs, the angle decreases and the bands return until finally the direct light from the returning sun washes them out.

Just something to note: Some people have a misconception about the danger to their eyes during a solar eclipse and believe the danger is increased during the eclipse. I knew a Mom that would not let her kids outside during an eclipse because of this misunderstanding. The danger comes from the fact that as the moon blocks more and more of the light of the sun it becomes less and less painful to look directly at the sun without protection. It is painful to look directly at the sun because of the intense light, but we feel nothing from the U.V. energy. If you look unprotected at even the last moments before C2 or just after C3 you will feel no pain because 98% of the intense light is being blocked, but you will be bombarding your eyes with damaging U.V.

The bottom line; there is no more danger to you eyes during an eclipse than any other sunny day, but most people don't stare at the sun for 5 minutes during a bright sunny day.

A marginally safe way to observe the sun and the eclipse, if you neglect to obtain a proper set of glasses, is from it's reflection on water in a black container. Water reflects less than 10% of the U.V. hitting it's surface and the black container (a plastic "leftover container" with the inside spray painted with black paint) will absorb most of the rest of it. Understand that you are still exposing your eyes to the reflected U.V. but probably less than sitting on the beach or swimming pool with no U.V. blocking sun glasses.
